channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: The Brew Crossword: High-volume turnout
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: How TV Networks Are Preparing for Election Night 2020
item.description: Bottom line: Don’t tell these networks traditional TV is dead.   A mudslide of early votes. Some tally them as they arrive, but others don’t even start until after polls close.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: The Historical Performance of the Stock Market Based on Presidential Party
item.description: What does that mean for stocks?   Regardless of party, the S&P performs better in a president’s first term than in the second.   Stocks have typically gained more when either party holds a simple majority in the Senate—not more than 60 of the 100 seats.   Bank of America Global Research analyzed historic S&P performance under presidents from both parties.   Investors wish they could take a long weekend in Aruba, but in 2020 there’s no such thing: Tomorrow is Election Day, which will determine what party holds power in D.C. for the next few years.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: How to Sell a Haunted House
item.description: So how do you sell a haunted house?   That seems to be the exception to rule, because haunted houses are typically not an easy sell. Both Lynnewood Hall (dubbed the world's largest haunted house) in Elkins Park, PA, and the house from The Silence of the Lambs are on the market. Depends on the state  In New York, if the seller has "claimed to the public at large" that the house is haunted, he or she must disclose the spooky status to buyers.   Believe it or not, hauntedness is a legal designation in the real estate industry.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Big Tech Reports Big Tech Earnings
item.description: Apple posted strong numbers for its fiscal Q4 that modestly beat expectations, with Macs and AirPods offsetting weaker iPhone sales.   The context: Apple has worked on shoring up its software and services, plus it’s boosted products like AirPods and the Apple Watch.   Facebook beat expectations on both revenue ($21.5 billion) and daily active users (1.8+ billion, up 12% yearly). After the bell yesterday, four Big Tech bigwigs dispatched earnings reports.   Google parent Alphabet also reported blowout earnings, with profits at $11.2 billion and revenue at $46 billion last quarter.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Business Insider Buys Controlling Stake in Morning Brew
item.description: Why the Brew was attractive: Morning Brew expects to bring in $20+ million in revenue this year, has been consistently profitable, and has incredibly good-looking newsletter writers.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: U.S. GDP Rose 7.4% on Quarterly Basis in Q3
item.description: Overall, GDP is down 3.5% this year.   On a quarter-to-quarter basis, Q3 GDP rose 7.4%, following a 9% drop in Q2. **Annualized rate: measured as if the economy will continue growing at that pace for a full year. But the third wave of Covid infections and the lack of federal stimulus could be a drag on those numbers.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Pennsylvania in the 2020 Election: The Frackstory
item.description: It's been an economic savior for some parts of the state that were hollowed out by the decline of manufacturing jobs, but some Pennsylvanians are against it on environmental grounds.   Biden is currently favored to win the state, per FiveThirtyEight.   + Miss any of our state-level stories this week? It's a swing state that boasts 20 electoral votes.   President Trump won Pennsylvania in 2016, but by only 44,292 votes...
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Netflix Raises Price for Standard, Premium Subscriptions
item.description: WarnerMedia's HBO Max, which parent company AT&T said has 57 million global subscribers. Netflix is expected to pass 200 million subscribers this year, and those dollars add up.   NBCUniversal's Peacock, which collected nearly 22 million users after three months.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Here’s the Deal on Joe Biden and Amtrak
item.description: But Amtrak always had a fierce defender in Joe Biden Biden protected Amtrak’s subsidies like Walt and Jesse protected each other against slighted kingpins. Throughout his lengthy career as a politician, Biden has associated himself Rachel-and-Monica-closely with train travel, both as a substantive legislative cause and an element of his folksy brand—to the point where some call him Amtrak Joe.  The first time he ran for president, in 1988, Biden launched his campaign from the back of a train.   He claims to have ridden over 2 million miles on 16,000-ish Amtrak trains.     Here’s the deal, folks: Amtrak is an unusual company  In that it’s actually a company/government agency hybrid, like the Postal Service.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Snapchat Crushed Earnings and Keeps Cruising Upwards
item.description: Analysts expected the slump to continue into Q3, but Snap streaked in the opposite direction by adding 11 million daily active users—which matched its first-quarter haul.   Bottom line: Snap’s stock is now up a very Zoom-esque ~158% on the year.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Week Ahead: October 26
item.description: testimony from Zuck, Jack Dorsey, and Sundar Pichai; earnings (Boeing, UPS, Gilead, Pinterest) Thursday: Q3 GDP data; earnings (Apple, Alphabet, Facebook, Twitter, Starbucks, Activision Blizzard); Halloween Eve Eve Friday: ExxonMobil earnings; The Mandalorian returns for Season 2; new Ariana Grande album; Halloween Eve  Saturday: Halloween
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Pot Legalization: 5 More States Toke Up the Issue
item.description: The state of play Eleven states plus D.C. have legalized recreational pot.   Next week, residents of five states—Arizona, Montana, New Jersey, South Dakota, and Mississippi—will vote on various legalization measures.     Voters may be eyeing the economic windfall that legalization can provide. Any suggestion otherwise stems chiefly from slander.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: ESG Funds See Record Inflows, but Questions Around Regulation Remain
item.description: ESG funds. These inconsistencies have led to awkward groupings, like fossil fuel company ExxonMobil's inclusion in one of BlackRock's ESG funds. Identifying companies rated highly on ESG metrics is an increasingly popular way for investors to deploy their money "responsibly."   What's ESG?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Brew Crossword: October 26, 2020
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Essentials, Issue #76: Live adventurously
item.description: .   Stay Sharp  Live on the wild side: Not all of us have the time or willpower to cycle 25,000 miles around the world, but we can all embark on microadventures.   Same interview.   Happy Place    Putt Sakdhnagool/Getty Images This week’s Happy Place is brought to you by Essentials reader Eric.   P.S. Go vote!   Dept. Here’s how to keep up with the 18-year-old pop star who is changing live music:  Read more about her mesmerizing livestream in the High Tea newsletter. Leading Off   Giphy Nobody else can pull off green hair and oversized clothing like Billie Eilish.   Good stuff: I’m about to make your Monday 20x better, especially for all the dog lovers out there.   Behind the screen: While counting down the days until season 2 of The Mandalorian, I’m nerding out about the technology replacing the green screen.   -------- See you on Thursday for a special Halloween issue.   Exercise your rights: In uplifting voting news, an astronaut voted from space, and here’s the liveliest voting line I’ve seen.   On the market: Live out your librarian fantasy by checking out the New York Public Library’s secret apartments.   Insomniac: If you never get in your eight hours, torment yourself with 52 stages of insomnia.
item.author: Rachel Cantor

item.title: Uber and Lyft are Spending Big on Prop 22
item.description: What's Prop 22? , that luggage is way too heavy. In other words, Californians are about to vote on the most expensive ballot measure of all time.   And by weight, we mean cash.   Read them here. Will it pass? This article is part of our weeklong series exploring state-level issues in the upcoming election.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Kazakhstan's Tourism Board Channels Borat With new Marketing Slogan
item.description: "Kazakhstan's nature is very nice, its food is very nice, and its people, despite Borat's jokes to the contrary, are some of the nicest in the world," Kairat Sadvakassov, deputy chairman of Kazakh Tourism, said in a statement.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Eye-Popping Numbers From the News
item.description: Here's a roundup from yesterday:  1.4 billion: That's how many face masks 3M has sold so far this year, per its earnings report. Comparable sales at Popeyes grew 17.4% in Q3. Popeyes, whose iconic fried chicken sandwich is still causing traffic jams in the drive-thru lane. can you guess which one?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden, Trump Face Off in FInal Debate
item.description: Zoom out: For the 45+ million Americans who already voted, this debate didn’t change much. Trump said Biden would "destroy the oil industry."   Climate: Biden said his plan would transition to cleaner industries, create millions of jobs, and get the U.S. to zero emissions. T-minus 11 days for everyone else. No pressure.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Tesla Rolls Out “Full-Self Driving” Beta That’s not Full Self-Driving
item.description: + While we’re here: Tesla is recalling nearly 50,000 Model S and X vehicles in China over potentially faulty front and rear suspensions.     What’s “full” self-driving?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: International News Roundup
item.description: Thailand: Apparently the mascots of Thai banks hold massive dance parties.   Slovakia: The government is trying to administer a coronavirus test to every adult over the next two weeks to tamp down a second wave of infections.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: TikTok Faces Its First Moderation Test With the Election Looming
item.description: TikTok has never allowed political ads, and no major U.S. politician has a TikTok account (even if a dance battle might speed up stimulus talks).   TikTok’s attempts to depoliticize itself while its users flood the platform with political content is an issue that its competitors have been dealing with for years.   But like that one uncle at Thanksgiving TikTok’s users just won’t stay out of politics.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Third Wave of Covid-19 Threatens U.S. Businesses
item.description: But with a record 83,000+ new cases reported both Friday and Saturday, a third wave of Covid-19 is already battering the country and threatening an uneven recovery for U.S. businesses.   In Europe, where cases have more than doubled in the last 10 days, Italy is requiring bars and restaurants to close early beginning today—its most intense restrictions since lifting lockdowns this spring.     Like the U.S., some countries are dealing with protests against new restrictions.   Plus, people are worried how well Covid will hit it off with the flu. Spain enacted a nightly curfew yesterday and will allow local authorities to restrict regional travel.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Jack Ma Talks Up Ant Group IPO
item.description: Ma sees lots of potential. The Chinese billionaire behind Alibaba and Ant Group may have officially retired from his corporate roles, but he's still got plenty of opinions... As for digital currencies?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Ant Group Will Become Largest IPO Ever
item.description: Our question: If Ant is now going to be the biggest IPO... Valued at around $313 billion, Ant will go public in Hong Kong and Shanghai in the coming weeks...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Tough Q3, Covid Outlook Wipe $35B From SAP Market Value
item.description: SAP was already dealing with some clouds In the last decade, SAP has moved to join its legacy tech peers IBM and Microsoft aboard the cloud computing bandwagon.   The cloud is cannibalizing the software licensing model SAP used to make its big bucks from. SAP who?   Against the backdrop of rising Covid-19 infections, SAP cutting profit targets and hunkering down for a couple more quarters could be a worrying sign for other tech companies. At least you didn't lose $35 billion (we hope). Think you had an unproductive Monday?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Facebook Tests the Cloud Gaming Waters
item.description: But Facebook is taking a fundamentally different approach than its rivals, focusing on free games, like the Farmville of yesteryear, that you can play within the Facebook app at your leisure.    Bottom line: While rolling out a completely free-to-use service might not make business sense on the surface, Facebook makes money by keeping users on Facebook.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: NASA Study Discovers Definitive Presence of Water on the Moon
item.description: NASA had teased a big announcement about the moon for weeks, and yesterday it finally spilled the beans: There is water on the moon.   To clarify, scientists have been hypothesizing about the presence of H2O on the moon since 1971.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Vaccine Scene: Where Things Stand As Of Oct. 27
item.description: Big picture: The U.S.’ vaccine game is high-stakes.   FYI, our vaccine is the only one being tested that involves a single dose.   The study hasn’t been peer reviewed yet.   Still, we just barely beat Q3 earnings estimates yesterday.    Pfizer: Optimistic. But if everything goes smoothly, we could turn the tide by July of next year. Any slip-ups in the program—such as only four out of six candidates proving effective, or not enough people getting vaccinated—could mean we’ll be dealing with the virus well into 2023.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Governments Test Shorter Quarantines to Improve Compliance
item.description: 14-day quarantines were reduced to seven days in France, while Belgium, Spain, and Germany are cutting them to 10.   Canada, Thailand, and the U.S. are also considering chopping quarantines for international visitors. Which is why a handful of governments are shortening quarantines in hopes that more people will actually start complying, the WSJ reports.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: 5 and a 1/2 Steps for Fact Checking Your Social Media Feed
item.description: Disneyland2go on Twitter To make sure an account is legit, you can do a cursory scroll for red flags to see if any official websites link to it. It’s best to find the original post and fact check that instead.   You can also fact check an image using techniques from Step 2 and 3: Use Google to research the photo’s background (who’s in it, what’s happening) or look it up on fact-checking sites like Snopes.   The following websites are useful resources to quickly make sure a fact checks out: AP Fact Check and FactCheck are dedicated to verifying/debunking claims, while Snopes specifically tackles viral social media news.   Step 2: Check your source Ask: Who posted this content?   So when you feel extremely emotional about a post, rein in your urge to click, and continue your fact check.   If a visualization seems suspicious for any of the above reasons, or if it’s just too crazy to be true, you can reverse image search the same way you would any other image. Is the data all from one source, or multiple? 🚩: Stats, graphs, and charts that tug violently at your emotions    Data is Ugly on Reddit Do: Make sure any charts you’re looking at are set up in a way that isn’t misleading, like the one above.   Many doctored images fit a pattern.   The Media Manipulation Casebook is like its own degree in fact-checking. 🚩 Famous people doing things that feel out of character; any text on the image (especially on a white background); no photographer/website credited   archive.   Case study: You don’t need to be a pro YouTuber to create viral fake news. Even if the people behind the account are who they say they are, it’s important to check that they are who you think they are.   Detecting deepfakes is so complicated that our recommendation really is just to be skeptical and check everything else you can in the post.   Netflix’s The Social Dilemma is a good doc for learning more about algorithms. If Uber posts about Prop 22 (a ballot measure that directly impacts their business), it’s best to check another, independent source like a local newspaper. Step 4a: Verify the image Ask: When was this image taken? One of the best ways to debunk a fake photo like this one is to reverse image search it on Google.   As we barrel roll toward the election, the news you read on social media won’t just affect your vote, but liking or sharing it could send posts spiraling into the East Australian Current that is going viral.   Facebook has been taken to court for the misinformation spread like peanut butter across its platforms, while Twitter’s war on fake news has led to many dustups with POTUS—most recently over a blocked New York Post article about Joe Biden.   If the source is shady or the post takes you on that emotional roller coaster I mentioned earlier, take it with a grain of salt or go into full fact-checking mode.   Go Deeper Read between the lines by learning how to spot logical fallacies.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: 15 of the Best Products on Amazon for $10 or Less
item.description: For the creative: Brainstorm new ideas with a pack of Post-Its ($10).   For Earth’s greatest advocate: Shop with Ecowaare produce bags as an alternative to plastic produce bags ($9).   For the neat freak: Scrub away with the best sponge, Scrub Daddy ($10).   For the at-home barista: Brew a successful latte with a milk frother ($9).    For the roommate who always forgets their keys: Hang up this keyholder magnet to ensure you never lock yourself out again ($10).    For the budding baker: Fall in love with this Silpat baking mat. Tip: If you shop at Amazon Smile, Amazon will donate to your favorite charitable organization. Btw, give our excellent podcast a listen here.
item.author: Rachel Cantor

item.title: Founder of Utah-Based Tech Company Qualtrics Buys the Utah Jazz
item.description: In 2018, just before Smith was set to take Qualtrics public at a $5 billion valuation, European software giant SAP offered $8 billion to buy the company, which Smith accepted.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Texas's Economic Makeover Will Make Election Day Interesting
item.description: What it means for Election Day Data compiled by the University of Houston shows that Texas's major metropolitan areas now account for 69% of the statewide vote, up from 52% in 1968.   Bottom line: It would still take a historic upswell of Democratic support to flip the state in this election.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Google, Facebook, and Twitter CEOs Spar With U.S. Lawmakers over Section 230
item.description: “Congress should update the law to make sure it’s working as intended.”   Here are the best soundbites from the feisty affair: "Section 230 is the Internet’s most important law for free speech and safety.” Big Tech’s version of the Avengers assembled yesterday, when Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, and Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai faced off against a Senate panel over the widespread protections Section 230 offers their tech empires.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Heathrow no Longer Europe’s Busiest Airport
item.description: Heathrow said it had been overtaken by Charles de Gaulle in Paris as the busiest airport in Europe, with Amsterdam Schiphol and Frankfurt “close behind.”   Passenger testing is important because it allows travelers to avoid long quarantines following a trip.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Trump’s Promises to Wisconsin Manufacturing Workers Disappoint
item.description: In 2018, President Trump visited Wisconsin to break ground on what he called “the eighth wonder of the world,” a high-tech manufacturing facility for TV screens that would bring 13,000 jobs and $10 billion in investment to the swing state.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Why Europe Locked Down—Again
item.description: The moves made the Continent’s stock markets swoon  The Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, suffered its worst one-day drop since September ahead of Macron’s announcement.   France’s neighbor Germany also enacted a partial, month-long lockdown.   Bottom line: The U.S. and Europe have resoundingly failed to hold onto the progress made over the summer against the virus.   The WHO said the European region accounted for almost half of the new Covid-19 cases reported last week. German restaurants, bars, gyms, concert halls, and theaters will close starting Nov. 2.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Q3 2020 Recap
item.description: Professional golf has been underway for months with only minor testing headaches, while the pandemic-era versions of the Tour de France, the U.S. Open in tennis, and the Kentucky Derby went off smoothly. If the first two quarters of the year meant us coming to terms with a global pandemic, Q3 saw us settling into a ~new normal~ of face masks, parking lot dining, and saying "whoops, sorry!"   So what about K-12?   Q3 was the busiest for public offerings since the dot-com era.   That was a lot.   The election, for one.   Over the last three months, extreme weather events made more intense and frequent by human-induced climate change have ravaged communities across the country. There's actually good news.   Pulse check on the economic recovery  It's...   So why are biz leaders wearing out DocuSign?   Looking ahead On the monetary side...   On the corporate side...   On the fiscal side...   Looking ahead... School Reopenings Test Students, College Towns, and Parents After schools across the country closed their doors in the spring, John Krasinski hosted virtual prom, graduation ceremonies were streamed online, and at least one student accidentally said, “Sup, b****?”   Soccer: A  This summer, the National Women's Soccer League became the first major U.S. sports league to return to action from the Covid break, while the MLS has already welcomed fans back in certain states.    How the Economic Recovery Fared in Q3 As the ink dries on Q3, nearly 900,000 Americans are filing new jobless claims each week.   The Atlantic Coast produced so many big tropical storms that the World Meteorological Organization depleted its list of 21 names by September and is now using the Greek alphabet. Even where students can attend school, many parents have chosen not to enroll them. University of Iowa students angered Twitter (an easy feat, really) by lining up for downtown bars in Iowa City, which earlier this month had the fourth-highest Covid-19 cases per capita in the U.S. But for local businesses like The Airliner bar, students returning to campus is their only lifeline—revenue was $0 in April.   Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images Parts of the West Coast have been ablaze since August, with a record 3.7 million acres burned across California. Climate change is no longer one of those problems. the M&A could keep flowing, but experts think the IPO frenzy will settle by late October.   Whether you want to relive summer 2020 or would rather pretend it never happened, we present: the Brew's third quarter recap. Basketball: A+  Zero NBA players have tested positive for Covid-19 since entering the famous "bubble" in Orlando. The Tampa Bay Rays, the Brew’s July pick to win it all, entered the postseason as the top team in the American League. But with the election and a Supreme Court fight ahead, don't hold your breath for more emergency aid until the Christmas lights come out.
item.author: Neal Freyman
